summary: IAV is an enveloped and negative-sense RNA virus. it encodes at least 12 viral proteins, including two envelope glycoproteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) and three polymerase subunits of virus-specific RNA polymerase. viral HA protein first binds to sialic acid-containing receptors located on the host cell surface and triggers internalization of the viral particle through endocytosis. vRNP, M1, and viral envelope proteins assemble viral particles. then released from the cell surface to produce viral progeny. cellular transcription corepressor ZBTB25 is involved in IAV replication. SUMO proteins belong to the ubiquitin-like protein family and are covalently linked to a lysine residue within the consensus sequence (KXE) of the target protein via a multienzymatic cascade of E1 activating enzyme, E2 conjugating enzyme, and E3 ligase. SUMO-specific proteases catalyze deconjugation of SUMO from substrate proteins using their isopeptidase activity. antiviral response involving the expression of type I and II IFNs and IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) the secreted IFN activates the JAK/STAT/ISGF3 pathways. subsequently induces the production of ISGs, including RIG-1, MDA5, IRF7, STAT1 and many others. two shZBTB25 clones (shZBTB25-a and -b) produced very low ZBTB25 levels. similar data were obtained using small interfering RNA (siRNA) oligomers (siZBTB25-a and -b) to knock down ZBTB25 expression. these results suggest that ZBTB25 plays a positive role during IAV replication.
